section.title: Documenting the Animal Premises
section.para: Computer software applications can be thought of as abstract mechanisms for modeling and recording elements and attributes of the real world. The Tracker software application simply models and documents the animals and event histories associated with a livestock animal premises.

section.title: Tracker Premises Documents
section.para: Whether it is word processing documents, spreadsheet documents, or presentation documents, today's computer users are most familiar with software applications that create and manipulate documents that describe specific instances of information.

The Tracker enables users to create, transform and edit Livestock Premises documents that represent specific Animal Premises. Premises documents are displayed and manipulated with Tracker Editors, Wizards, and utilities. The attributes of the premises, the animals in the premises and the events associated with these animals are specified with Premises documents.
Tracker Model document files utilize a .premises file extension to distinguish them from other types of files.

section.title: Tracker Data Model
section.para: Because all user activity centers around the creation and manipulation ofTracker Premises Documents, understanding the structure of Tracker Premises documents is the easiest way to learn to use the information management facilities of the Tracker.

All Tracker Premises documents structurally conform to the Tracker Premises Model. In the Tracker Premises Model a single Premises contains zero or more animals. Each Animal must have at least one but may have more than one (identification) tag. Each Tag must have at least one but may have more than one associated event.
In the figures below you will find a graphic representation of the core elements of the Tracker Premises Model. Tracker Premises Model Core Elements

listitem.para: The core elements of the Premises Model are depicted as the blue rectangles in the figure.
The notation within the elements are the attributes of the element.
The notation between the elements are the relationships of the elements.

section.para:
The following table offers a text explanation of the Element Relationships. Core Elements of the Premises Model
Element Name
Relationship to other Elements
Premises
There is one premises in a document
Animal
A premises can have zero or many animals
Tag
An Animal can have one or many tags
A Premises can have zero or many tags that are unassigned
Event
A Tag can have one or many events
Tracker supports multiple Event types. Tracker Event Types
